componenttext: Yes.

headline: General Electric Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Drilling BOPs were definitely down substantially, but Surface was up. We report it as one group, Drilling & Surface.
componenttext: So Drilling BOPs were definitely down substantially, but Surface was up. We report it as one group, Drilling & Surface.

headline: General Electric Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I know the H price is not in the index, but can you give some color on how that's pricing versus expectation?
componenttext: Okay. And I know the H price is not in the index, but can you give some color on how that's pricing versus expectation?

headline: General Electric Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's not in the index. I would say, without giving away any real competitive information, I would say sequentially, pricing is improving order to order.
componenttext: Well, it's not in the index. I would say, without giving away any real competitive information, I would say sequentially, pricing is improving order to order.

headline: General Electric Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one really quick one on FX. Is the $0.01 headwind or so that you're talking about for 2015 now incremental to what you were thinking previously? And the reason I ask is you had $0.02 in Q...
componenttext: Okay. And then just one really quick one on FX. Is the $0.01 headwind or so that you're talking about for 2015 now incremental to what you were thinking previously? And the reason I ask is you had $0.02 in Q...

headline: General Electric Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeff. So what I was trying to say was when we did the framework in December, if you look at that  versus -- I did that math at $1.15, $1.16. The move from December to $1.15 to $1.16 for us meant that we were working with the $0.01 headwind that we wo
componenttext: Yes, Jeff. So what I was trying to say was when we did the framework in December, if you look at that  versus -- I did that math at $1.15, $1.16. The move from December to $1.15 to $1.16 for us meant that we were working with the $0.01 headwind that we would figure out.

headline: General Electric Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: But again, I'd come back to there's other mitigants to a lot of the stuff as you look through the system. We're just trying to give you guys...
componenttext: But again, I'd come back to there's other mitigants to a lot of the stuff as you look through the system. We're just trying to give you guys...

headline: General Electric Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm not changing guidance in any way. I'm not changing...
componenttext: I'm not changing guidance in any way. I'm not changing...

headline: General Electric Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're trying to give you guys the pieces because I think that's -- we want you to know how we think about it, but there's a lot of other things inside the company that we use to offset it, just like we did in Q4.
componenttext: We're trying to give you guys the pieces because I think that's -- we want you to know how we think about it, but there's a lot of other things inside the company that we use to offset it, just like we did in Q4.

headline: General Electric Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: General Electric Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Andrew Obin from Bank of America.
componenttext: The next question comes from Andrew Obin from Bank of America.

headline: General Electric Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a question -- 2 questions. So the first, part of the reason for creating Oil & Gas was to actually to deliver to national oil companies in an environment like this. Could you share some of the conversations that you are having with these customers an
componenttext: Just a question -- 2 questions. So the first, part of the reason for creating Oil & Gas was to actually to deliver to national oil companies in an environment like this. Could you share some of the conversations that you are having with these customers and how are you guys positioning versus the competition? And are you seeing that your structure is actually making a difference? And from the outside, how do we know that it does make a difference?

headline: General Electric Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, look, I would say again, there's not one-size-fits-all, but I think clearly, the national oil companies look differently at this cycle than some of the integrated oil companies do. So I would just say in the case of a company like Saudi Aramco, they
componenttext: Well, look, I would say again, there's not one-size-fits-all, but I think clearly, the national oil companies look differently at this cycle than some of the integrated oil companies do. So I would just say in the case of a company like Saudi Aramco, they're going to continue to produce, and there's a number of strategies that are associated with that, similarly to a company like PETRONAS and things like that, and then there's other places that are in more stress. So look, I would just echo back, Andrew, the comment I made in December. We like the Oil & Gas business. We like how we're positioned in it, and we think these cycles give us an opportunity to pick up market position similar to what we did in the Aviation business and the Power business and other businesses. But short of going through private conversations with customers, I can just say that we still think with a lot of the NOCs -- or a certain segment of the NOCs, there's still potentially going to be some good business to be done in 2015.

headline: General Electric Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just to follow up, what's the latest strategic thinking on Energy Management and the progress that they're making?
componenttext: Just to follow up, what's the latest strategic thinking on Energy Management and the progress that they're making?

headline: General Electric Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Look, I think we're in a pretty good strategic position. This is a business where Alstom adds some capability and scale, and our pathway has to be one that gets us to margins that are more competitive with the ABBs and the other players in this industry,
componenttext: Look, I think we're in a pretty good strategic position. This is a business where Alstom adds some capability and scale, and our pathway has to be one that gets us to margins that are more competitive with the ABBs and the other players in this industry, and we can accept nothing less. So I think the way I look at it right now, Andrew, we're in it to win. We expect margin accretion and earnings growth year after year in this business. And here's one where the ceiling is very high in terms of what we should be able to do in this business.

headline: General Electric Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Shannon O'Callaghan with UBS.
componenttext: The next question is from Shannon O'Callaghan with UBS.

headline: General Electric Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe first for Jeff Bornstein. I mean, when you think about driving this thing from down 80 bps gross margin this year to up 50, I mean, how do you see that sort of phasing through '15 numerically? And also, where are you and Dan and Jamie at in terms of
componenttext: Maybe first for Jeff Bornstein. I mean, when you think about driving this thing from down 80 bps gross margin this year to up 50, I mean, how do you see that sort of phasing through '15 numerically? And also, where are you and Dan and Jamie at in terms of what you're doing to drive that?

headline: General Electric Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So right now, Shannon, we're doing very deep dives with each business. And basically, I hate to get too tactical, but basically, we're starting with the outcome and building back the project decks from there. So on every element of product and service cos
componenttext: So right now, Shannon, we're doing very deep dives with each business. And basically, I hate to get too tactical, but basically, we're starting with the outcome and building back the project decks from there. So on every element of product and service costs, direct material, inflation, deflation, direct material usage, warranty, scrap, operating cost per hour of our different facilities, every labor, et cetera, building the project decks that support delivering at each of the segment levels their share of gross margin improvement at the segment level. And that's where we are today. Jamie, in parallel with that, is continuing to drive and support the businesses with ERP, which is a big part of giving them visibility and driving our ability to consolidate, et cetera. So we are in the process right now of building very detailed, action-oriented plans that have every dollar of cost between sales and the gross margin line owned by somebody with a plan. So that's where we are today. I would say this is going to accelerate throughout the year. We're early in the process now, but I'm quite confident if we get out of the way we have programmatically around SG&A, I think we can make a big difference here. And I think there's a lot of opportunity, as Jeff said earlier, particularly around original equipment margins.

headline: General Electric Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's great, really helpful. And then in terms of just the U.S. Healthcare strengths, I mean, can you give us a little more color there? I mean, what are you hearing from customers? And where do you really think that market is and decision-making i
componenttext: Okay, that's great, really helpful. And then in terms of just the U.S. Healthcare strengths, I mean, can you give us a little more color there? I mean, what are you hearing from customers? And where do you really think that market is and decision-making is at this point?

headline: General Electric Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Shannon, the only 2 data points I can give you is just kind of what we saw, which was pretty good. We don't have the market data yet, so we don't know share and things like that, but we have good products and good activity, and we got to believe that w
componenttext: So Shannon, the only 2 data points I can give you is just kind of what we saw, which was pretty good. We don't have the market data yet, so we don't know share and things like that, but we have good products and good activity, and we got to believe that we gained a little bit of share. And then just, I would say, the other data point I could give you is conversational, which is, as I see hospital CEOs when I travel the circuit, you just get a lot more positive in terms of their ability to know what the next few years are going to be like to do their planning, to do their growth plans and things like that. And that didn't exist, let's say, 24 months ago. So we're guardedly optimistic, but it's too early to call it a trend, I would say.

headline: General Electric Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our final question comes from Julian Mitchell with Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: Our final question comes from Julian Mitchell with Crdit Suisse.

headline: General Electric Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just on the Healthcare business, you talked about how the Q4 performance was something of a blip, but I guess the profit drivers down, price and FX probably persist through the whole of this year. So maybe talk a little bit about why you're so confident t
componenttext: Just on the Healthcare business, you talked about how the Q4 performance was something of a blip, but I guess the profit drivers down, price and FX probably persist through the whole of this year. So maybe talk a little bit about why you're so confident that Healthcare earnings are going to rebound.

headline: General Electric Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Again, I would say, Julian, on the comment you made, this is -- as Jeff went through his presentation and stuff, there's always going to be concern about FX and stuff like that in this business. Nonetheless, the U.S. is just a big powerful driver of Healt
componenttext: Again, I would say, Julian, on the comment you made, this is -- as Jeff went through his presentation and stuff, there's always going to be concern about FX and stuff like that in this business. Nonetheless, the U.S. is just a big powerful driver of Healthcare profitability, mix, things like that. And so when I look at 2015, that, in addition to momentum we've got in Life Sciences and stuff like that, I think that offsets all the other, let's say, headwinds we might see in terms of FX and otherwise.

headline: General Electric Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Julian, I'd just add. I didn't -- if you took it that way, I apologize. I didn't mean to describe the Healthcare performance as a blip. What I meant to say was organically, the performance was better than headlined when you think about the impacts of FX.
componenttext: Julian, I'd just add. I didn't -- if you took it that way, I apologize. I didn't mean to describe the Healthcare performance as a blip. What I meant to say was organically, the performance was better than headlined when you think about the impacts of FX. And I completely agree with Jeff. I mean, when you -- the developed markets feel like they're getting stronger for Healthcare. We're going to have challenges in Russia or in some of the emerging markets, but the bulk of our -- percentage-wise, the U.S. is still the biggest single market we have in Healthcare, and we feel much better about the strength there than we have in the past.

headline: General Electric Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 23, 2015

headline: General Electric Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think in our working construct for the year, we expect value gap to be roughly what it was this year. So we ended this year at about $300 million net value gap and $300 million of value gap, and our expectation is that will likely be what 2015 look
componenttext: Yes, I think in our working construct for the year, we expect value gap to be roughly what it was this year. So we ended this year at about $300 million net value gap and $300 million of value gap, and our expectation is that will likely be what 2015 looks like.

componenttext: Yes, thank you. Before wrapping up, just a couple of quick announcements. The replay of today's webcast will be available this afternoon on our website. We'll be distributing our quarterly supplement for GE Capital later today. On Friday, April 17, we'll hold our First Quarter 2015 Earnings Webcast.

headline: General Electric Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great, Matt. I just want to reiterate as we close, the framework we've got for '15 really has a ton of strength and thoughtfulness in it in terms of the scenarios that we're seeing globally. So I would just echo that and just reiterate -- we talked about
componenttext: Great, Matt. I just want to reiterate as we close, the framework we've got for '15 really has a ton of strength and thoughtfulness in it in terms of the scenarios that we're seeing globally. So I would just echo that and just reiterate -- we talked about the new compensation plan that the leaders have inside the company. That really has each and every business aligned to deliver in a very effective way for our investors as we go forward, Matt. So I would just make those 2 points in closing.
