headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the General Electric Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] My name is Ellen, and I will be your conference coordinator today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this confere
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the General Electric Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] My name is Ellen, and I will be your conference coordinator today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the program over to your host for today's conference, Matt Cribbins, Vice President of Investor Communications. Please proceed.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to our third quarter earnings webcast. We issued the press release, presentation and supplemental earlier this morning on our website at www.ge.com/investor. As always, elements of this presentation are forward-looking
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to our third quarter earnings webcast. We issued the press release, presentation and supplemental earlier this morning on our website at www.ge.com/investor. As always, elements of this presentation are forward-looking and are based on our best view of the world and our businesses as we see them today. Those elements can change as the world changes.
For today's webcast, we have Chairman and CEO, Jeff Immelt; Vice Chairman and CEO of GE Capital, Keith Sharon; [ph] and an our CFO, Jeff Bornstein.
Now I'll turn it over to Jeff Immelt.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Matt, and good morning, everyone. The GE team had a good quarter and slow growth in a volatile environment. Organic performance was strong. Industrial revenue growth was up 4%, profit was up 9%, year-to-date industrial sale prorated is up 23%, and
componenttext:
Thanks, Matt, and good morning, everyone. The GE team had a good quarter and slow growth in a volatile environment. Organic performance was strong. Industrial revenue growth was up 4%, profit was up 9%, year-to-date industrial sale prorated is up 23%, and industrial segment margins are up 100 basis points.
Let me make a few comments on how we are seeing our markets more broadly. The U.S. is still okay, and Europe is appreciably better. Meanwhile, growth markets are facing some headwinds in resource, pricing and currency. Nonetheless, we are positioned to win some big fourth quarter deals in these markets in locomotives and power, Aviation and Power Conversion, which should support our growth objectives. And service provides a great buffer in times of uncertainty.
We made substantial progress on GE's portfolio transformation in the quarter. Alstom has been approved by the European Commission, and we expect this to close soon. The Fed has approved the Synchrony separation, and we expect to commence the share exchange next week. The net effect of this should be to return about $20 billion to investors in the form of share reduction.
Our GE Capital portfolio sales are ahead of plan. And with the wells announcement, we now expect 2015 signings of $140 billion to $150 billion. And we believe this will facilitate an incremental dividend from GE Capital of $2.5 billion in the fourth quarter or $3 billion for the year.
So if you look at our execution, we're tracking to meet or beat all of our critical goals. We're reconfirming our earnings outlook that we gave in the second quarter when we boosted the low end of our range. And our CFOA and cash return to investors will be at the high end of our framework. So Keith and I will now take you through a deeper dive on the portfolio moves.
For Alstom, all the major regulators have now approved GE's purchase of Alstom with remedies. We're comfortable with the outcome as the economic and strategic impact of the deal remains intact. We will divest to Ansaldo the GT26 new units and the GT36 technology and 34 of 720 service contracts in the installed base. We will retain the ability to do service for competitive units through PSM. Financially, we still expect to achieve $3 billion of synergies with $0.05 to $0.08 of earnings accretion in '16 and $0.15 to $0.20 by 2018. Alstom grows GE's installed base by 50%. [ph] In addition, they will substantially improve our position in renewables and grid. Alstom will achieve a strong return for investors, and we will give you more operating details on Alstom at a special meeting we plan to hold at late November.
Now over to Keith to give you an update on the GE Capital portfolio moves.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. As Jeff mentioned, we have received formal approval from the Federal Reserve to move forward with the split-off of Synchrony Financial as a stand-alone company. This is the final step in a project which we started
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. As Jeff mentioned, we have received formal approval from the Federal Reserve to move forward with the split-off of Synchrony Financial as a stand-alone company. This is the final step in a project which we started 2 years ago and is a key component in the transformation GE Capital.
We can't talk about the specific financial terms of this exchange until we launch. However, to provide some context, on the left side of the page, we show the time line and mechanics for the exchange. We plan to launch the split exchange next week, subject to market conditions. The offer period remains open for 20 business days from the time of launch. And at launch, we're going to set the offer terms with exchange, meaning the split discount that holders will receive in Synchrony stock when they exchange their GE shares, plus the exchange cap ratio, which is the maximum discount between GE and Synchrony share set at the time of the launch. The pricing for the split exchange will happen on day 16 to 18, and the offer closes on day 20, which would occur the week of November 16.
Based on precedents from other exchanges that have taken place and the current stock prices of GE and Synchrony, we anticipate to receive proceeds of between $18 billion and $21 billion, which translates to a buyback of 650 million to 750 million shares of GE. The range of outcomes is determined by the split discount, the exchange ratio and the movement of GE and Synchrony shares prior to and during the exchange up to pricing. We anticipate that we'll record a gain in GE Capital in discontinued operations, and that gain the size of which is dependent on the spinal split discount, will be embedded in the proceeds for the buyback, so will not have any impact on GECC capital ratios. I would really like to thank Margaret Keane and her team for the terrific work they've done to position Synchrony for this separation. In the next 30 days, we plan to retire 6% to 7% of GE shares.
Next, I'll give you an update on our progress executing the plan that we announced on April 10. On the top left of this chart is an update on the portfolio of sales. We are ahead of plan. And in the first 6 months since the announcement, we signed deals on $126 billion worth of any. Since 2Q, we signed $58 billion worth of transactions, the largest being the $30 billion sale of our distribution finance, vendor finance and direct line of businesses to Wells Fargo, which we announced earlier this week. We gave previous guidance that we would sign $120 billion to $150 billion of deals by year end, and we're a now raising the low end of that range to $140 billion given the progress we've made. We have closed $60 billion of sales to date, and we're on track to close $100 billion by year end.
On the bottom left, you can see our current view versus the goals that we established back on April 10. We're ahead on plan on asset sales, and we expect to largely be done with the exits by year end '16 instead of '17. Overall, we're on track to deliver the $35 billion of capital back to the parent. You can see on the top right that our pricing to date on the $126 billion is slightly ahead of plan at 1.4x price to tangible book. And the deal that we announced at Wells earlier this week will also at approximately 1.4x price to tangible book. As a result of the accelerated sales, we're giving up some the future income from the Hubble plan, but overall with our asset liability management actions, including the debt exchange that we completed, our current estimate of capital to be returned is still $35 billion.
In terms of timing of dividends, as we closed sales transactions in the fourth quarter, we expect our Tier 1 common ratio to exceed 14%, and we plan to pay a dividend of approximately $2.5 billion in the fourth quarter, subject to our governance process. That would result in $3 billion for 2015, which is $2 billion higher than the original plan. In addition, we are on track for the $18 billion of dividends that we previously said would come in 2016. Our goal is to apply for CCD designation, which based on our view of transaction closings, our target is to file in the first quarter of '16. If you combine the Synchrony split with the 2015 transaction closings, we expect to end 2015 with around $175 billion of ENI, around $200 billion lower than year end 2014.
I'd really like to thank the GE Capital employees who have accomplished a lot in the last 6 months, and the team is focused on substantially completing the business exits by the end of 2016.
Let me turn it back to Jeff.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Keith. And now I'll briefly go through GE's industrial operations. Our year-to-date orders are down 4% organically. We faced some tough comps in orders compared to third quarter '14 when total orders grew by 22% and equipment orders grew by 31%. O
componenttext:
Thanks, Keith. And now I'll briefly go through GE's industrial operations. Our year-to-date orders are down 4% organically. We faced some tough comps in orders compared to third quarter '14 when total orders grew by 22% and equipment orders grew by 31%. Organically, developed markets are up 18% year-to-date with growth markets down 7%, excluding a large onetime GE9X order.
Our year-to-date orders in China are up 1%. Service grew by 6% organically, and our progress was broad-based. Power Gen services grew by 10%, Aviation spares grew by 28% and Healthcare was up by 4% organically. Power & Water, Energy Management and Healthcare orders were up 9% organically. However, Aviation and Transportation had significant onetime orders placed in the third quarter of '14 with the GE9X in Tier 4. These 2 products alone had $6 billion of orders in the third quarter of '14. Oil & Gas orders reflect the impact of industry dynamics. Our organic orders decline was 32%. It is not unexpected. We continue to compete well in the market and have not seen cancellations. Importantly, there's substantial equipment orders where we've been selected technically, but they've been delayed. So we're confident in our market position.
Across the company, we have a strong funnel of orders for the fourth quarter, and we expect orders performance to improve. On execution, the GE team executed very well in the quarter. Our organic revenue growth was up 4% with 6 to 7 segments up. Our relative position, both in product and geographic diversity, has never been stronger. Globally, revenue in the U.S. was up 5%, and Europe organic growth was up substantially, while growth markets declined by 7%. Year-to-date revenue was positive in the Asean, China, sub-Saharan Africa, Latin America and Middle East and North Africa. Meanwhile, regions like Russia, Canada and Australia have been hard hit by natural resource dynamics. Services were up 8% organically. Growth for software and analytics was up 16%, [ph] gaining momentum from our digital investments. At Minds & Machines, we launched Predix and now have more than 20,000 developers. We're expanding partnerships with important customers like Boeing, Exelon and BP. Service growth was broad-based with Power up 9%, Aviation up 17%, Transportation up 10%, and Healthcare up 3% organically. We're winning with new products. The H turbine has 67 technical selections with 21 in backlog. Power Conversion revenue grew by 15%, behind multiple new product launches. Our aviation engines are achieving market leadership by meeting customer commitments with superior execution. We now have 10,000 LEAP engines in backlog. Life Sciences had 8% organic growth in the quarter, and we have 2 important wins for bioprocess manufacturing in China. We launched Current as a way to capitalize on 72% LED growth and the opportunity to build a strong presence in the C&I energy efficiency space. Margins continue to be a great GE story. Segment op margins grew by 100 basis points with growth in gross margins of 80 basis points, and we've expanded our value gap by $300 million year-to-date and expect this to continue.
Our product margins are expanding, and analytics continue to drive productivity and services. Restructuring is delivering substantial benefits. And in all, we think our margins can continue to grow. This is our 10th straight quarter of margin expansion, so we have real momentum.
I would like to highlight the work of our Oil & Gas team as a good example of our execution. In a tough environment with organic revenue declining by 7%, they grew margins by 100 basis points organically and held earnings. This will position them well in a volatile industry.
Our cash is also good story for the year. Industrial CFOA is up 23% year-to-date. Industrial free cash flow was up 53%. And as is typical, we expect a strong fourth quarter, where we expect a $2 billion reduction in working capital similar to last year.
The great portfolio execution mentioned by Keith will allow for upside in our cash performance. Based on accelerated progress in capital asset sales, we should be able to dividend an additional $2.5 billion to the parent in the fourth quarter, and this should be $3 billion for the year. This will put the company at the high end of our CFOA range. And an effective Synchrony execution should return about $20 billion to investors through a share exchange, and this will put us at about $30 billion of cash return to investors for the year through dividend and buyback.
We still expect appliances to close in the quarter. This is not a complicated transaction. Appliances is a highly competitive industry with at least 7 manufacturers and 21 brands. Electrolux wants to close and is working hard to do so.
So the GE balance sheet is very strong, and we will finish the year with substantial liquidity. And now over to Jeff to go through operations.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Jeff. I'll start with the third quarter summary. We have revenues of $31.7 billion, which were down 1% in the quarter. Industrial revenues, including corporate, were down 2% to $25.8 billion. Industrial operating, plus vertical EPS, was $0.
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Jeff. I'll start with the third quarter summary. We have revenues of $31.7 billion, which were down 1% in the quarter. Industrial revenues, including corporate, were down 2% to $25.8 billion. Industrial operating, plus vertical EPS, was $0.29, up 16% year-over-year, with industrial up 9% and verticals up 15%. Operating EPS number of $0.32 adds in other continuing GE Capital activity, including the consumer segment, headquarter runoff and other exit-related items, which I'll cover in more detail on the GE Capital page.
Continuing EPS of $0.28 includes the impact of nonoperating pension and net EPS of $0.25 includes the impact of discontinued operations. The total disc ops impact for the quarter was a negative $347 million, which included $1 billion of exit-related noncash charges. These charges are within the framework of the $23 billion exit impact that we communicated in April. Partly offsetting the charge was income associated with operations in CLL and real estate, which were moved to disc ops early in the year. As Jeff said, we generated $6.5 billion of CFOA year-to-date, which was down 9% [indiscernible] by lower GE Capital dividends. However, industrial CFOA was $6.1 billion year-to-date, up 23%. The GE tax rate was 17%, bringing the year-to-date rate to 20%, which is in line with our current estimate for the total year rate. The GE Capital reported rate was a negative 6% in the quarter, which includes tax benefits associated with the plan to shrink GE Capital. The vertical tax rate was 0%. As we communicated previously, as we complete the GE Capital restructuring, we expect the vertical tax rate to be low double digits.
On the right side, you can see the segment results. Industrial segment revenues were down 1% on a reported basis but up 4% organically, reflecting about 5 points of headwind from foreign exchange. Foreign exchange was a $1.2 billion drag on industrial segment revenue and $165 million impact on industrial segment op profit. Despite this headwind, industrial segment operating profit was up 5%. And organically, the industrial segments were up 9%. GE Capital vertical earnings of $351 million in the quarter were up 55%.
Next, I'll go through the earnings walk. Consistent with last quarter, we included a walk of the different elements of our earnings so that the dynamics are clear, given all the moving pieces with GE Capital. Starting with the first column on the left and working down. Industrial operating net income was $2.6 billion, and vertical income was $351 million for a total industrial plus vertical's operating earnings of $2.9 billion. The GE Capital consumer segment earned $795 million during the quarter, which I'll cover later. On the other GE Capital line, we incurred $411 million of cost driven by exit-related tax and restructuring charges, headquarter runoff, operating expenses and excess interest. As a result, total operating earnings were $3.3 billion, including nonoperating pension costs, continuing earnings for $2.9 billion. Discontinued operations were a charge of $347 million, which I discussed in the previous page. Adjusting for these items, net earnings for the quarter were $2.5 million. [ph] In the center and far right columns, you can see the associated EPS numbers and a variance versus prior year.
Next page, on onetime items. We had $0.02 of charges related to ongoing industrial restructuring and other items as we continue to drive the cost competitiveness of the company. Charges were $346 million on a pretax basis and $244 million after tax. About 45% of those charges related to restructuring in our Oil & Gas business as we continue to execute on our cost-out program. We had no industrial gains in the quarter.
On the bottom of the page, you can see the fourth quarter estimate. We're expecting gains from Appliances signaling and embedded systems transactions in the quarter. For the year, we continue to expect gains in restructuring to be balanced on an EPS basis. We have increased our expected restructuring from $0.11 to about $0.14 due to the hard gains we expect for the year. We have additional attractive restructuring opportunities including Alstom, which allows us the higher gains.
Now I'll go through each of the segments, including Power & Water. Orders in the quarter were up 8% and up 13% organically. Equipment orders were up 7% to $3.5 billion on strength in distributed power, higher by 61%; renewables up 2%, partly offset by Thermal down 6%. Distributed Power was higher driven by 2 fast-track power deals in Indonesian Ghana and our first order for first 6 LM 6000 plus [ph] units in Thailand. The new LM 6000 PF plus contains 56 combined cycle efficiency, which is the highest in its class. It takes half the time to install versus its predecessor and can start up to full power in about 10 minutes.
Renewables orders were up 2%, up 14% excluding FX on strong international orders. Unit volumes were lower at 821 versus 839 a year ago, but megawatts were up 9%. Thermal orders were down 6%, down 2% ex FX. We took orders for 22 gas turbines versus 23 last year. The business booked 4 H orders in the quarter, 2 in Pakistan, 1 Korean and 1 in the U.S. This brings our total H units in backlog to 21 with an additional 47 technical ones, a 7-unit increase from the second quarter.
Service orders grew 8% to $3.4 billion, driven by strength of PGS, up 10%. We continue to see success in our upgrade campaigns including AGP's, dry load our flex, all of which enhance the performance of our machines. In the quarter, we booked 22 AGPs, up 4 from the third quarter of last year. Revenues in the quarter were up 1% and higher by 7% organically. Equipment revenue was down 6% driven by Thermal down 10% on 16 gas turbine shipments versus 26 a year ago. And Distributed Power was down 13% on lower engine volume, principally driven by weak demand in the gas compression market. Renewables revenue were up 8% and up 19%, excluding exchange on higher shipments of 735 wind turbines versus 642 last year.
Service revenues were strong, up 9% led by PGF, up 13%, driven principally by upgrade sales. AGPs totaled 22 in the quarter versus 18 a year ago. All profit was higher by 7% and up 10% organically. Margins improved 100 basis points driven by service growth and cost productivity.
As we look to the fourth quarter, no change of the framework we've given you on gas turbines and Distributed Power. Wind is turning to the low end of the range we've given you previously of 3,000 to 3,200 turbines.
Next, Oil & Gas. The business continues to perform in a very difficult environment. Orders in the quarter were down 38% and down 32% organically. All segments on lower orders given the constrained CapEx environment and project delays. Equipment orders were down 60% with TMS down 57%, driven by large Canadian LNG pushout. Subsea was down 81%, with softness in both drilling and low stream. Downstream was down 58%. Surface was down 49% on lower rig counts, and M&C was down 22% on softness in flow and process technology.
Service orders for the quarter were down 13% but down 4% organically, principally driven by Subsea and Surface down 26% and 39%, respectively. And that was partly offset by TMS, which was up 4% and up 20% organically on higher installations. Backlog in the third quarter ended at $22.3 billion, down 7% year-over-year. Revenues in the quarter were down 16% to $3.9 billion and down 7% organically. Foreign exchange had a $400 million impact on revenue.
Equipment revenues were down 18% and down 8% organically, driven by Surface, down 36%; and Subsea lower by 12%, down 3% ex foreign exchange. Organically, TMS was down 3%, and downstream was up 12%. Service revenues were down 14% and down 5% organic with MNC down 2%. All profit was lowered by 12% versus last year and flat organically. Foreign exchange was a $75 million headwind in the quarter. The business continues to execute on cost of material deflation. Value gap was positive with a very modest price impact. Margins improved 70 basis points and 100 basis points, excluding the effects of exchange. Through 3 quarters, revenues are down 13% and down 4% organically. Operating profit is down 10% reported and up 5% organically. We expect volume pressure to persist into the fourth quarter. However, given the strong execution on cost out, we believe that for total year, organic all profit, we will be about flat year-over-year or slightly better versus the flat to down 5% guidance we provided earlier. The team is making strong progress in achieving the $600 million of cost-out goals for 2015 and is well positioned to deliver $1 billion plus cumulatively of cost out through 2016. In aviation, underlying travel demand continues to grow robustly, higher by 6.6% year-to-date August, with strength domestically and internationally. The Middle East and Asia Pacific continue to be particularly strong. Airfreight volumes grew 2.6% through August. Orders in the third quarter of $6.5 billion were down 35%. The third quarter of 2014 included large orders received in the Farnborough Airshow. Equipment orders were down 58%, driven by commercial orders. Last year, we booked $3.8 billion of GE9X orders versus $600 million of GE99x orders this quarter. GEnx orders of $600 million were up 3x, driven by strength in China, and we had $800 million of LEAP CFM orders in the quarter. Commercial engines backlog of just under $30 billion is higher by 22% versus last year. Military orders were down significantly on non-repeat of international campaigns last year and soft U.S. demand. Services were very strong. Service orders grew 13% on strong commercial experience growth of 28% at $39.5 million a day, and military services were higher by 76%. This was probably offset by overall volume being down. Revenue in the quarter was up 5% to $6 billion. Equipment revenues were down 6%, with commercial down 1% and military down 20%. We shipped 64 GEnx units versus 65 last year. And services revenues was up 17% with commercial experience higher by 22% and military up 16%.
Operating profit was up 7% driven by strong services volume and value gap. Margins expanded 30 basis points in the quarter. So another solid quarter from the Aviation team. The LEAP testing performance remains on track with the first new installs expected to be in service in mid-2016.
Next up is Healthcare. Orders of $4.5 billion were down 4% reported but up 3% organically. Geographically, the U.S. was down 1%. Europe was up strongly, ex foreign exchange, by 11%, and down 5% reported. China was flat, and the Middle East grew 15%.
In terms of product lines, Healthcare systems orders were down 7% but up 1%, ex foreign exchange. In the U.S., orders were up 2% driven by strength in CT and MR, which were higher by 10% and 15%, respectively, partially offset by weak x-ray. The U.S. appears to have performed in line with the market. Europe were strong again, up 7% organically, and that's the fifth consecutive quarter of positive organic growth for us in Europe. The Middle East grew 22%. China was down 14% as orders continue to be impacted by lower public tenders. The private sector orders are growing at double-digit rates in China but up a much smaller base than the public market.
Life Sciences orders grew 11% organically and 4% reported. Bioprocess grew 23%, excluding FX, with very strong demand in Europe, up 42%; and in China, up 162%. Healthcare revenues were down 5% in the quarter, up 2% excluding the impact of foreign exchange. Healthcare systems was up 1%, and Life Sciences grew 8%, excluding FX.
Operating profit in the quarter was down 10% and down 4% organically. Negative leverage was driven by lower value gap and higher new product spend, which more than offset the cost productivity in the business. Margins contracted 90 basis points in the quarter. The third quarter was impacted by lower-than-expected volume in the growth markets and accelerated new product spread to drive future growth. The business has seen strong customer interest in productivity analytics, and as a result, has accelerated their migration to the Predix platform and development of Predictivity applications. In the fourth quarter, we expect this level of higher product investment to continue, and we expect growth markets to remain challenging and developed markets to continue to show positive organic growth.
In Transportation, North American carloads were down 2.2%, primarily driven by lower coal and petroleum, down about 9%. That was partly offset by 2% intermodal growth. Year-to-date, rail volume is down about 1%. Orders in the quarter were down 77% or about $3 billion, as we expected, driven by locomotives. In the third quarter of '14, we took a threefold increase or about 1,100 units in order for Tier 4. 2014 large order intake, combined with the current global commodity cycle, is pressuring demand for incremental locomotive power. However, we are working on several large opportunities and expect fourth quarter locomotive orders to be much stronger.
Revenues in the quarter grew 3%, driven by services, up 10%. And locomotive equipment revenues are up 11%, partially offset by mining. Operating profit was up 11% driven by volume, productivity and deflation, more than offsetting Tier 4 ramp cost. Margins improved 160 basis points.
In Energy Management, orders of $2.1 billion were up 2% and up 8% organically, driven by strength in renewables in our Power Conversion business, which grew order 16%, up 26% organically. Power Conversion's renewable orders were up over 4x on deals won in conjunction with both GE and Alstom, which offset the weak Oil & Gas Marine segment.
Digital Energy orders were up 20%, and industrial solutions was down 13%. Revenues in the quarter were down 2% reported but up 6% ex exchange. Organically, Power Conversion was up 15%, Digital Energy was up 8% and Industrial Solutions was flat.
Operating profit was higher by more than 2x to $127 million in the quarter. Higher earnings driven by strong cost productivity and value gap, partly offset by negative FX. Margins improved 390 basis points in the quarter.
And in appliances and lighting. For the segment, revenues grew 8% in the quarter with appliances up 10% on strong volume and lighting up 5%. The U.S. appliance industry was up 8% with retail up 9% and contract up 7%. Lighting continue to grow LEDs. LED revenue grew 65%, partially offset by a 15% decline in traditional products. LEDs now account for 39% of lighting revenue, up from 25% a year ago. All profit in the quarter was up 88% driven by material deflation and cost productivity.
Next, I'll cover GE Capital. Our vertical businesses earned $351 million this quarter. That's up 55% from prior year, driven by transactional gains and lower annual impairments in our Aviation business, partially offset by Oil & Gas impairments in our energy business. Portfolio quality remains stable as GE Capital finished the quarter with 0 delinquencies and no AOGs.
Working down the page. Consumer earned $795 million during the quarter, up 20% on gains related to portfolio exits from the international platform, partially offset by Synchrony minority interest. Our share of Synchrony earnings was $493 million, as in prior quarters, CEO, Margaret Keane, will hold Synchrony's earnings call later today. As Keith covered, we received approval from the Federal Reserve to proceed with the Synchrony separation and intend to launch the share exchange next week, subject to market conditions.
GE Capital corporate generated $411 million loss in the quarter, driven by GE Capital exit-related tax and restructuring charges, excess interest expense and headquarters operating cost. Discontinued operations end of the quarter was $347 million loss, driven by $1 billion noncash charge associated with the execution of our portfolio exit strategy, partially offset by operating results in the underlying businesses. These charges are in line with $23 billion total cost construct we shared with you in April.
Overall, GE Capital reported $387 million of earnings, and we ended the quarter with $176 billion of continuing ENI, excluding liquidity. The verticals ended the quarter with $78 billion of ENI, excluding liquidity. Our liquidity levels remain strong, and we ended the quarter with $97 billion, including $15 billion attributable to Synchrony. As part of GE Capital's internal reorganization, we launched a debt exchange to capitalize our international entity and to better align our assets and liabilities from a maturing liquidity perspective. The exchange was oversubscribed. We accepted $36 billion of new bonds, which were priced on October 5. And we'll settle the transactions on October 26. Our Basel III Tier 1 common ratio was 13.7%, which is up 230 basis points from the second quarter. We expect the GE 14% Tier 1 common ratio by year end inclusive of the additional $2.5 billion dividend that Keith mentioned previously.
Just some highlights on the right-hand side of the page. The verticals are on track to deliver $1.5 billion of earnings in 2015. Asset sales are ahead of plan with $126 billion signed and $60 billion closed. Once completed, the Synchrony exchange will trigger the consumer segment to move to discontinued operations. Given our significant progress, we plan to apply for CPT designation in the first quarter of 2016. In the last 6 months, Keith and the GE Capital team have continued to deliver operationally and are well ahead of the plan on the portfolio transformation we shared with you in April.
With that, I'll turn it back to Jeff.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff. Just to conclude, we have a few updates on the operating framework. We've kept the industrial EPS expectation at $1.13 to $1.20. If appliances close, we will be closer to the high end of this range, and our execution on our organic growth, m
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff. Just to conclude, we have a few updates on the operating framework. We've kept the industrial EPS expectation at $1.13 to $1.20. If appliances close, we will be closer to the high end of this range, and our execution on our organic growth, margins and corporate cost remain strong. We expect the GE Capital verticals to be at least $0.15 with more strength in GE cash, and capital asset sale should be at least $100 billion, with more coming in the first quarter. CFOA should be about $16 billion, and free cash flows plus divestitures will be about $15 billion, assuming that appliances closes. And we expect to return $30 billion to investors about, reflecting the impact of Synchrony. GE is executing on its investor commitments and is on track for its 2015 goals. Our portfolio transformation is happening at an unprecedented pace. We have a focused infrastructure business with leading positions in our markets, and we're positioned to grow faster than our competitors with a strong dividend. We're growing operating and gross profit margins and making corporate smaller, with nearly a $200 billion backlog of services that positions the company well for any cycle, and we're transforming GE into the world's premier digital industrial company in a unique position to drive outcomes for customers and grow margins.
I'd like to take a moment to acknowledge the work of the GE team. Last quarter, we completed our largest industrial acquisition, completely repositioned GE Capital and launched one of the largest-ever IPOs. At the same time, we're winning in the market and delivering strong financial results. I'm very proud of their work.
Now Matt, back to you for questions.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff. Lots to talk about. Let's open up the lines up for questions.
componenttext: Thanks, Jeff. Lots to talk about. Let's open up the lines up for questions.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Scott Davis with Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Scott Davis with Barclays.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Is there a sense, Jeff and either Jeff, I guess, but Jeff Immelt. But is there sense with the follow-up you've seen in others that any risk we are entering a bit of an industrial recession, particularly as it relates to growth markets?
componenttext: Is there a sense, Jeff and either Jeff, I guess, but Jeff Immelt. But is there sense with the follow-up you've seen in others that any risk we are entering a bit of an industrial recession, particularly as it relates to growth markets?

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Scott, what I would say, kind of going around the world is, U.S. gets a little bit better every day. Europe is appreciably better. But clearly, the growth markets are highly differentiated in terms of their performance and have some headwinds as it per
componenttext: So Scott, what I would say, kind of going around the world is, U.S. gets a little bit better every day. Europe is appreciably better. But clearly, the growth markets are highly differentiated in terms of their performance and have some headwinds as it pertains to oil prices and things like that. On balance, Scott, we see as much activity as we've ever seen. So the quoting activity, the deal activity, things like that is still quite robust. Business for us in China is still pretty good, which is a big market. And so we still see a fair amount of opportunities out there, even amongst the volatility. So I really believe that we can still accomplish our long-term goals in the world we see today. And then I will just remind you that we got $200 billion backlog of services at 70% or 80% of our earnings. It's growing organically 8%. So we've got a pretty robust underpinning of the total company as we go forward. But the quote activity is as robust today as it was 6 months ago or a year ago.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then it's a little bit of a strange question, but those of us who followed you guys for a long time have seen, I think, a higher sense of urgency or at least on execution level that's been pretty high in the last year or so, I gu
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then it's a little bit of a strange question, but those of us who followed you guys for a long time have seen, I think, a higher sense of urgency or at least on execution level that's been pretty high in the last year or so, I guess, in the last 6 quarters have beaten your margin targets or so. What do you attribute -- I mean had a big change in compensation structure that kicked in in January. I mean are we seeing just the benefit of past investment sort of kind of pulling through? And how do you think about that least -- how do you attribute really this higher level of execution and how GE is different today maybe than it was maybe just 3 years ago?

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I would say, Scott, I would say again, great team. The compensation plan clearly helps. I think we made the investments 3 or 4, 5 years ago that are helping us today in product lines and globalization and things like that. I mean we don't -- we have as
componenttext: So I would say, Scott, I would say again, great team. The compensation plan clearly helps. I think we made the investments 3 or 4, 5 years ago that are helping us today in product lines and globalization and things like that. I mean we don't -- we have as robust of an NPI pipeline as we've ever had. And we're not dependent on any one country. We've got a very diversified country mix, and that's some of the stuff that John Rice have done. Now the last thing I would say, Scott, is look, there's no way to describe what it feels like to run GE where the team knows exactly what it has to do over the next 3 years. I mean, our plan -- we can't guarantee exactly what the macro environment is going to be. But between the GE Capital actions, buyback stock, organic growth, integrating Alstom, you got a leadership team that knows precisely what we need to do for investors over the next 3 years, and that is a place we haven't been and certainly since the financial crisis. And that -- I think just helps everybody. It helps people who own the stock, and it gives the leadership team, I think, extra momentum as we go forward.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Deane Dray with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question comes from Deane Dray with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: I had been thinking it might be too early to ask about some specifics for your Oil & Gas outlook for 2016. But you did just disclose the cost-out plan and the increase to cumulative to $1 billion there. So hopefully, you can share some of your assumptions
componenttext: I had been thinking it might be too early to ask about some specifics for your Oil & Gas outlook for 2016. But you did just disclose the cost-out plan and the increase to cumulative to $1 billion there. So hopefully, you can share some of your assumptions, maybe getting as granular and revenues and out profit for Oil & Gas next year?

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Deane, I would say in that it's a market that is so visible and volatile, I think -- I'd start by reflecting a little bit on what we've done this year. So the team, I think in a very tough environment, has gotten after the costs, has executed in the ma
componenttext: So Deane, I would say in that it's a market that is so visible and volatile, I think -- I'd start by reflecting a little bit on what we've done this year. So the team, I think in a very tough environment, has gotten after the costs, has executed in the market, has driven services. And so I think you'd say, if you reflect back on where we were in the fourth quarter last year and then where we sit today, I think our Oil & Gas team has done a fantastic job as it pertains to this year. And I think if we look forward and just -- we don't assume that the market gets appreciably better. We would say that revenue might be down 10% to 15% next year and then operating profit might be down 10% to 15% next year. And that we hold margins in a tougher environment. And that's the kind of feel that we have. And again, we still want to go through and do all of our normal fourth quarter planning on the company, but I just think it's important to investors to have some visibility in terms of how we think about Oil & Gas and triangulating backlog and things like that.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just to clarify that 10% to 15%, that's an organic number?
componenttext: And just to clarify that 10% to 15%, that's an organic number?

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Right.
componenttext: Yes. Right.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good. And related to oil and gas, and you mentioned going back to the fourth quarter when oil was really still in a free fall. The outlook meeting, Jeff, you said you could be opportunistic in looking at assets in Oil & Gas and would love to hear what you
componenttext: Good. And related to oil and gas, and you mentioned going back to the fourth quarter when oil was really still in a free fall. The outlook meeting, Jeff, you said you could be opportunistic in looking at assets in Oil & Gas and would love to hear what you're thinking today. Is there any size parameters that you can share?

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Look, guys, we still like this industry. I would go back, Deane -- and look, we never -- as we build in our portfolio in Oil & Gas, we've never thought about it reflecting $120 per oil or anything else. Our investments really made along the lines of -- we
componenttext: Look, guys, we still like this industry. I would go back, Deane -- and look, we never -- as we build in our portfolio in Oil & Gas, we've never thought about it reflecting $120 per oil or anything else. Our investments really made along the lines of -- we felt like the industry was going to be growing in technical intensity, customer solutions that over time the Oil & Gas business would look a lot like our aviation business or power business and things like that, and that's what led to the investment. So we're a long-term player in Oil & Gas. We like the industry. We're committed to the industry. I think as it looks -- as we look at opportunities and where we are today, anything would have to hurdle about buying back their own shares. And so we'll be opportunistic. We'll be disciplined, and we have -- we have an alternative that we think is still quite attractive for us of buying back our own shares.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good. That's helpful. And just last question from me is, one of the moving parts of the 2015 framework that is outside of your control is the timing, the assumption of the close of appliances. That's really -- that's in the hands of Electrolux. It's in th
componenttext: Good. That's helpful. And just last question from me is, one of the moving parts of the 2015 framework that is outside of your control is the timing, the assumption of the close of appliances. That's really -- that's in the hands of Electrolux. It's in the hands of the regulators. So can you just remind us what the P&L impact could be if that close gets pushed into 2016?

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so you'll recall we talked about something that looks like a $0.06 a share gain associated with appliances. So if it got pushed out of the year, we'll probably rethink a little bit about what we're doing in restructuring in the fourth quarter. We wou
componenttext: Yes, so you'll recall we talked about something that looks like a $0.06 a share gain associated with appliances. So if it got pushed out of the year, we'll probably rethink a little bit about what we're doing in restructuring in the fourth quarter. We would consolidate a full quarter of appliance earnings, which should be a bit of an offset. And more likely than not, that would probably entail a breakup fee. So we still think we're well within the range of $1.13 to $1.20. But probably, that would push us to the bottom end of that range versus being at the top. So we've thought through that, and we also thought through it in terms of cash. I think we're fine. We're closing on Alstom and doing everything we need to do around cash flow even without closing appliances.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think, Deane, the biggest assumption is still that we close this deal. I think Jeff's given you -- I think it's always good to scenario plan. But base assumption still is that we finish. I don't see any reason why we should. But to your point, it's not
componenttext: I think, Deane, the biggest assumption is still that we close this deal. I think Jeff's given you -- I think it's always good to scenario plan. But base assumption still is that we finish. I don't see any reason why we should. But to your point, it's not completely under our control.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Steven Winoker with Bernstein.
componenttext: The next question is from Steven Winoker with Bernstein.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: So since you start to talk about 2016 a little bit, I'm going to just push the envelope here. The way I'm looking at it, anyway, if you hit that midpoint around 115 and 120, talk about on 2015 EPS, it looks like $1.17. You're telling us you got $0.10 from
componenttext: So since you start to talk about 2016 a little bit, I'm going to just push the envelope here. The way I'm looking at it, anyway, if you hit that midpoint around 115 and 120, talk about on 2015 EPS, it looks like $1.17. You're telling us you got $0.10 from Synchrony. You've got something like, based on the check buybacks, $0.06 to $0.08. You got Alstom now. Talking about $0.06 minimum. So without assuming any other growth from your industrial business, that's up like 20 -- I mean more than $0.20 there. And then Jeff, not sure what you guys are thinking for that, but certainly starting to get into that well north comfortable of $1.50, especially if you could hold Oil & Gas flat. Is that -- am I thinking about this in the right way?

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, what I would say, certainly, the pieces you're putting together, Steve, kind of hang together, right? I would say Oil & Gas is going to be down next year. That's got to be the working assumption. I think the focus Jeff and I are going to have is to
componenttext: Well, what I would say, certainly, the pieces you're putting together, Steve, kind of hang together, right? I would say Oil & Gas is going to be down next year. That's got to be the working assumption. I think the focus Jeff and I are going to have is to try to offset that with lower corporate as we think about next year. So we want to run corporate lower. And then I would say, look, we're going to give you guys a full estimate on all the other pieces of our industrial outlook in December. But look, we've got strong services, strong services growth, big backlogs. And we're going to win -- we're going to win some nice orders in the fourth quarter. And I just -- I feel like we're going to look pretty good next year in the world we see today. So...

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jeff, I think you got it exactly right. I don't think you can start with the premise of Oil & Gas flat. Having said that, Alstom is going to contribute -- EPS accretion is going to contribute. No question about it. Lower corporate. We expect to be better
componenttext: Jeff, I think you got it exactly right. I don't think you can start with the premise of Oil & Gas flat. Having said that, Alstom is going to contribute -- EPS accretion is going to contribute. No question about it. Lower corporate. We expect to be better operationally in the segments. And we expect EPS is going to grow double digits next year, for sure.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Nigel Coe with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: The next question comes from Nigel Coe with Morgan Stanley.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just -- I just wanted to just dig into 4Q. And obviously, the orders primarily are a function of the tough prior comp. The current backlog is pretty flat with where it was in 3Q. So I'm wondering if you could just maybe put some finer points on organic in
componenttext: Just -- I just wanted to just dig into 4Q. And obviously, the orders primarily are a function of the tough prior comp. The current backlog is pretty flat with where it was in 3Q. So I'm wondering if you could just maybe put some finer points on organic into 4Q? Are you running up 4% [ph] year-to-date? I'm wondering how you view organic into 4Q?

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we've got quite a range here on our expectation for fourth quarter order. But generally speaking, we expect them to comp much better than what you saw in the third quarter, both headline and organically. So we've got some big orders in Transportatio
componenttext: Well, we've got quite a range here on our expectation for fourth quarter order. But generally speaking, we expect them to comp much better than what you saw in the third quarter, both headline and organically. So we've got some big orders in Transportation. Some big orders in Power & Water we're looking to deliver in the fourth quarter. We expect Aviation to be slightly better. So we think sequentially, the fourth quarter is going to look much better than the third quarter, for sure.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Are we talking [indiscernible] or revenue orders, Nigel? Because I think revenue in Q4 is going to look fairly comparable to what it's been year-to-date, right?
componenttext: Are we talking [indiscernible] or revenue orders, Nigel? Because I think revenue in Q4 is going to look fairly comparable to what it's been year-to-date, right?

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015

componenttext: Okay. So nice to see the higher GE Capital dividend for '15. With the Wells deal and Synchrony now done, real estate range, is 14% Tier 1 still the right base to be using given that all those things are now sort of clearly on their way out? And how are the international consumer sales? Are there any things that would make you still be using 14%?

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Shanno, this is Keith. That's sort of the framework we agreed to with the regulatory oversight that we had. So I don't see us changing that until we ultimately earn under that same framework. Right now, as you know, we ended the third quarter at 13 7. Hav
componenttext: Shanno, this is Keith. That's sort of the framework we agreed to with the regulatory oversight that we had. So I don't see us changing that until we ultimately earn under that same framework. Right now, as you know, we ended the third quarter at 13 7. Having where the asset sales in the fourth quarter, we'll go up above 14. We expect the dividend $2.5 billion in the fourth quarter based on those assets sales in our governance process. And then we're on track for what we said we do in '16. But I don't -- I don't see that threshold really changing until you have a different regulatory environment. That's what it's so important for us to continue to shrink. That's why it's important for us to target applying to not be a SIFI in the first quarter. I think that's going to take some time. And then when we get it done with that, we still have our international regulators. So I think you should assume that that's the threshold for some period of time for us, and we need to continue to exit the businesses in a rapid pace and build a capital so that we can distribute it back to the parent.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question on Healthcare. The profits, ex currency, were up in Q2. They're down mid-single-digit Q3. And you talked about R&D being height in the slides. So maybe just give an update on the cost progress in Healthcare, particularly given the vo
componenttext: Just a quick question on Healthcare. The profits, ex currency, were up in Q2. They're down mid-single-digit Q3. And you talked about R&D being height in the slides. So maybe just give an update on the cost progress in Healthcare, particularly given the volume outlook in emerging markets and the fact that pricing is still very challenging. I think you talked before about Healthcare profits growing this year. I think they would clearly be down. But maybe give us some look in terms of the cost base entering next year.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I would say -- first, just to echo part of your question, I think the developed world is better. So U.S. and Europe are getting better. The emerging markets are mixed for Healthcare, but more headwind than tailwind. What Jeff said, in terms of really t
componenttext: So I would say -- first, just to echo part of your question, I think the developed world is better. So U.S. and Europe are getting better. The emerging markets are mixed for Healthcare, but more headwind than tailwind. What Jeff said, in terms of really trying to convert our Healthcare IT business and get it on Predix and spend a little bit of incremental R&D on that side of the business, I think it's something that we wanted to do this year to give us some momentum going into next year. And then I think the business has a whole series of variable cost productivity and product cost-out programs that are going this year that have yet to bear fruit that I would expect to roll into well into next year. So I think -- look, I think the markets are challenging. We did some onetime investment this year, and it's our expectation that the team can execute better going into -- the rest of '15 and going into '16.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would just -- I'll give you a little bit of color on the third quarter, since you asked for it. Definitely, price was challenge in the quarter. We're down 1.9 points of price, so we had a negative $100 million value gap. That was definitely a challenge.
componenttext: I would just -- I'll give you a little bit of color on the third quarter, since you asked for it. Definitely, price was challenge in the quarter. We're down 1.9 points of price, so we had a negative $100 million value gap. That was definitely a challenge. But this actually got pretty good productivity. We're well over $100 million of total cost of productivity in the quarter. And really, what swung here was volume was a bit lighter than we thought it was going to be, largely emerging markets. And we had about a $50 million [ph] incremental spend on R&D year-over-year to accelerate the programs we talked about. And that's where the challenge came through.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just further to Julian's questions on Healthcare. We've seen emerging markets become a much higher-volume business over the past few years and developing markets had a lot of regulatory dust settling here. So just wondering if there are any permanent evol
componenttext: Just further to Julian's questions on Healthcare. We've seen emerging markets become a much higher-volume business over the past few years and developing markets had a lot of regulatory dust settling here. So just wondering if there are any permanent evolutions or resets in the served markets there where we kind of we think what health -- what levels Healthcare performs at over the next 5 years?

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't think so. Obviously, China has been a very strong growth market for Healthcare for quite a bit of time. You got to remember, 74% of orders in roughly revenues come from developed markets still. Even with all the emerging market growth we've seen i
componenttext: I don't think so. Obviously, China has been a very strong growth market for Healthcare for quite a bit of time. You got to remember, 74% of orders in roughly revenues come from developed markets still. Even with all the emerging market growth we've seen in Healthcare, we sold about almost 3/4 from the U.S., Europe, Japan. So I don't think there's any change in the geographic footprint of where we think Healthcare is going or where the growth is going to come from. We've got some particular markets that are challenging based on commodities FX and [indiscernible], you think about the Russia, the Middle East. Places like Iraq are very, very tough to comp year-over-year. And we actually feel a little better that China is stabilizing a little bit for Healthcare. The performance this quarter sequentially was better, and we think the tendering process is ultimately going to pick back up. When you think about China, the underlying fundamentals haven't changed [indiscernible] 1.5 billion people. They're still building hospitals. The private market in China is growing 15% to 20% a quarter. The slowdown of the public tender is part of the campaign, the government's been running there is put -- put some slowness in what we've seen in terms of order. But I don't know there's much of a change in footprint here on a go-forward basis, and we're still 3/4 developed market-driven.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask a question just about -- if we're heading into industrial recession here, and you may disagree with that premise, could you just talk a little bit about the prospect for combating deflation? Because if we had a deflationary environment, we
componenttext: I wanted to ask a question just about -- if we're heading into industrial recession here, and you may disagree with that premise, could you just talk a little bit about the prospect for combating deflation? Because if we had a deflationary environment, we have kind of a multiyear down cycle where we kind of looking for a bottom in terms of volumes and cutting price, I mean isn't the portfolio actually set up for that just given the installed base of equipment and the service streams you have? Maybe if you just comment on that a little bit.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: So rob, again, I back in just -- U.S., a little bit better every day. Europe, stable to up. And then emerging markets, volatile, right? So I think that's -- revenue past for miles on Aviation still positive. Demand -- I would say for the gas and Wind busi
componenttext: So rob, again, I back in just -- U.S., a little bit better every day. Europe, stable to up. And then emerging markets, volatile, right? So I think that's -- revenue past for miles on Aviation still positive. Demand -- I would say for the gas and Wind business and power, more positive than negative, right? Oil & Gas, tough for sure. U.S. market in Healthcare growing better, slow and emerging markets. In other words, the first thing I'd say is, the picture is a slow growth in volatility picture. And I think there's still pockets of growth out there pretty universally. And then I would say, look, the fact that we're big installed base, recurring revenue model, margin efficient, capital efficient, I think that's a positive for GE in this cycle. And then our value gap continues to run positive, right? So the ability of us to kind of source well in the marketplace is a tailwind not a headwind.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would just add, the fact we have $250 billion [ph] backlog is very, very important in that kind of environment. $200 billion of that in the service [indiscernible] So from a price perspective, that's quite important. We're all about products and service
componenttext: I would just add, the fact we have $250 billion [ph] backlog is very, very important in that kind of environment. $200 billion of that in the service [indiscernible] So from a price perspective, that's quite important. We're all about products and service cost. So to maintain our profitability and grow it and to be competitive, we have got to drive it to the same dollars of deflation that you're suggesting. So we are laser-focused on this. The product and service costs competitively is just as important as the actual technology we're selling. So we are on top of those.

componenttext: Just a couple of cash and liquidity-related questions. First, on the capital side, if stuff is going a little bit richer than you thought, why not upside to the $35 billion of capital return over the program? And then just on the industrial side, if you kind of work through the pieces, you're kind of guiding 80% free cash flow conversion on industrial. Is there anything going on this year that kind of is conspiring negatively to that number? Should we see higher conversion into next year? Maybe if you could just kind of walk us through those dynamics.

headline: General Electric Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jeff, it's Keith. I'll just cover a little bit on the $35 billion. As we said, we do have a little bit of price that we're getting. Price to tangible book is ahead of what our plan was by a bit. And that's been offset by the fact that we're selling faster
componenttext: Jeff, it's Keith. I'll just cover a little bit on the $35 billion. As we said, we do have a little bit of price that we're getting. Price to tangible book is ahead of what our plan was by a bit. And that's been offset by the fact that we're selling faster. We try to say that on the page by a lot of those transactions were estimated to be later in '16 and into '17. And by selling them early, we're foregoing that future income. On the other hand, in total, we're expecting about 1.1x price to tangible book. We're a little ahead. You can see the U.S. assets that we've sold mostly so far are selling at 1.4x price to tangible book a little ahead of what we thought 1.3. And then the rest of assets, we think, we got price right. Overall, just a little ahead of the 1.1x for the total $200 billion of sales. So I think we're right on the $35 billion, and we feel pretty good about it.

componenttext: Yes, and [indiscernible] excuse me -- on CFA for the year. We think our cash conversion ratio on CFOA and cash flow for the year is closer to 84%, 85% not 80%. So we actually think we're going to have a decent performance on CFOA. We talking about our goal to get to 95% over the next 2 to 3 years. We're laser-focused on that. Didn't suggest that any point in time we're going to do that in 2015.
